results.content:
Overall this course was pretty disappointing. It feels disorganized in structure and Hemil doesn't use latest JS syntax features (ex arrow functions). 
When there are projects, only the final github code is provided. There are no boilerplates with the project setup to start from, and Hemil often doesn't walk you through the installation for the different packages needed. This often leads to errors when you build the project from scratch (ex for SCSS and testing).
The 2 projects are pretty interesting and Hemil shows some pretty cool things. However, he makes suggestions for what to add as homework but never provides a solution for those suggested extra features. 

All in all, this course is good is you want a surface-level introduction to the topics: it gives you a solid overview of the concepts and possibilities. But beyond that, there are much better resources out there.
results.content_html:

results.content: This is a really good course for someone who needs to brush up on React or if they know a bit of React and want to learn Hooks, Redux, and the basics of Typescript. I recently graduated from a 3-month immersive boot camp and this course definitely helped pad my existing knowledge.
results.content_html: This is a really good course for someone who needs to brush up on React or if they know a bit of React and want to learn Hooks, Redux, and the basics of Typescript. I recently graduated from a 3-month immersive boot camp and this course definitely helped pad my existing knowledge.

results.content: The course is fairly short but sweet! Hemil seems to cover the most important topics and explain the concepts very well. Not having previous experience with React, I wish he would have provided some examples of using React classes for comparison. But overall I am happy about choosing this course instead of a very long one that focuses on some specific project development.
results.content_html: The course is fairly short but sweet! Hemil seems to cover the most important topics and explain the concepts very well. Not having previous experience with React, I wish he would have provided some examples of using React classes for comparison. But overall I am happy about choosing this course instead of a very long one that focuses on some specific project development.

Very nice lineup and overall coverage of relevant topics nonethless.

results.content: I must say going through this course got me up to speed with hooks. Following along was fun and also enjoyable. My favorite sections where that of the PropTypes, Flow and TypeScript. Highly recommended. Thanks for the great course!
results.content_html: I must say going through this course got me up to speed with hooks. Following along was fun and also enjoyable. My favorite sections where that of the PropTypes, Flow and TypeScript. Highly recommended. Thanks for the great course!

results.content:
I took the entire course. I learned a lot. The course felt like it would be better on YouTube. Almost every video was a new example and he wanted you to do npx create-react-app for each example. That would have been sooo many projects, so instead I just replaced my App.js file each example. 

Also, I did not feel like the concepts were connected to each other when they were taught. For example, it felt like the hook videos were all recorded on different days because he would redefine something as if it was the first time he covered the content but he covered that idea 3 videos ago.

Certain elements/ concepts did not go into as much detail as I would have liked. When we would do an examples it felt like we were just copying him because he knew the solution instead of teaching it to us why you do step A and then step B. It felt more like "Ok so then you do this and then you do this" just because that is the way it is.  I wanted to come out of this feeling like I could apply these ideas to different problems, not just solve these simple ideas.

I did learn a lot on hooks, these were just issues that held me back from being excited about taking the course.
results.content_html:

results.content:
The most important thing : This is not a react course for people who know 0 react ! You must be familiar or have watched another React course( Colt Steel, Grider)

Pros: 
-A very good recap of the concepts 
-He is using 2020 information, other courses use 2018
-He is not wasting time at all. 
-Hooks parts are very good, I wished they were a little bit more long.
-In total a great recap course with original content. Many courses are doing the same thing

Cons:
-Very little explanation on some concepts. 
-A Hooks + Context entire section project would be the best because it's a popular way of using hooks and it's absent.

Conclusion: I liked this course. If you know react but don't know how to use hooks, this course will learn you very well and easy and it will learn you some best practices. I found the instructor on youtube(techsith) and from there I arrived here. I must say that the content there is amazing and you should 100% check it out. The interview playlists are amazing.
results.content_html:

I found the instructor on youtube(techsith) and from there I arrived here. I must say that the content there is amazing and you should 100% check it out. The interview playlists are amazing.

results.content:
Hemil is extremely great explainer. From my point of view he has very good pace. I mean he's like not hurrying up at all, of course he is speeding up sometimes, but only when it's really needed to wake someone up (if he is very fast) and to play with attention or just to move much closer to something more interesting. Hemil is well thinking over wordings (It makes understandable english for everyone who is not fluent it yet perfectly).

As a good teacher he try to stay in one logic line always, not to do many things at one time. Good concentration on every little detail, fast feedback in case of misunderstanding something and clear explanation in order to fill any gaps in a knowledge React / Javascript, thanks very much to him for all of this at once! 

I'm pleased and I think that all my React code would be written on Hooks soon and I believe that would be covered with tests on React Testing Library as much as possible.

I can't recommend this course.

Examples are poorly thought out. Best practices are barely mentioned and glossed over. Multiple libraries like redux, mobx and testing are mentioned but barely shown.

Walked out from the lessons without learning anything really since I always needed to go back to the documentation and learn what is it this time that wasn't mentioned in the lesson.

In useEffect lesson, there was a warning by linter which the professor ignored. ???
In react lessons "there is no way to explain it". 

I'm sorry but this is not what you want to see or hear from a teacher.
results.content_html:
I can't recommend this course.

Examples are poorly thought out. Best practices are barely mentioned and glossed over. Multiple libraries like redux, mobx and testing are mentioned but barely shown.

Walked out from the lessons without learning anything really since I always needed to go back to the documentation and learn what is it this time that wasn't mentioned in the lesson.

In useEffect lesson, there was a warning by linter which the professor ignored. ???
In react lessons "there is no way to explain it".

I'm sorry but this is not what you want to see or hear from a teacher.

results.content:
The author did a fantastic job on this course.  You can tell he put a lot of time and energy into it.  I think he has an excellent approach of introducing concepts with small projects. This prevents massive code blocks of a large project that uses concepts you haven't learned yet.  I wish he had sped up the time he is typing.  He types while he talks which slows progress down, but that is a minor point.  His English is excellent and I was able to understand everything he said, which is not the case in every Udemy course I have taken.  I've been using React for several years, and when the author started running through the basics of React, I started losing a little patience, as most of it I thought I already knew.  But you what?  I learned some things, even in the basic sections.  Two thumbs up for that.

He didn't do a great job explaining Redux.  I've used it for years.  A diagram of how it works (actions, store, how the view updates) would have been helpful if I was unfamiliar with Redux.  If you are unfamiliar with Redux or state management, I recommend some supplemental reading.
results.content_html:
The author did a fantastic job on this course. You can tell he put a lot of time and energy into it. I think he has an excellent approach of introducing concepts with small projects. This prevents massive code blocks of a large project that uses concepts you haven't learned yet. I wish he had sped up the time he is typing. He types while he talks which slows progress down, but that is a minor point. His English is excellent and I was able to understand everything he said, which is not the case in every Udemy course I have taken. I've been using React for several years, and when the author started running through the basics of React, I started losing a little patience, as most of it I thought I already knew. But you what? I learned some things, even in the basic sections. Two thumbs up for that.

He didn't do a great job explaining Redux. I've used it for years. A diagram of how it works (actions, store, how the view updates) would have been helpful if I was unfamiliar with Redux. If you are unfamiliar with Redux or state management, I recommend some supplemental reading.

results.content:
TL;DR:
This course covers all the concepts you need to know in order to quickly learn and get productive with React and it covers them all in a concise manner. Techsith explains them by breaking them down into short and easy to understand code examples as usual and we keep building onto them throughout the course. By the end of it, you will be comfortable using hooks even with async Redux actions in your projects.

Longer Version:
This course covers all the built in hooks but also teaches how to write your own custom hooks from scratch. It covers handling events, HOCs, Router, Redux + Thunk + Mobx with examples. It also explains how life cycle of components changed for good with hooks (it is less complex now). I especially liked the Redux part since it was very thorough and easy as I always had problems with Redux.

It covers unit testing React components with Jest, type checking and 2 fun projects to solidify all the concepts we learnt. It also shows how writing reusable components is necessary since it makes maintaining code easier in the long run and also saves our time.
results.content_html:
TL;DR:
This course covers all the concepts you need to know in order to quickly learn and get productive with React and it covers them all in a concise manner. Techsith explains them by breaking them down into short and easy to understand code examples as usual and we keep building onto them throughout the course. By the end of it, you will be comfortable using hooks even with async Redux actions in your projects.

Longer Version:
This course covers all the built in hooks but also teaches how to write your own custom hooks from scratch. It covers handling events, HOCs, Router, Redux + Thunk + Mobx with examples. It also explains how life cycle of components changed for good with hooks (it is less complex now). I especially liked the Redux part since it was very thorough and easy as I always had problems with Redux.

It covers unit testing React components with Jest, type checking and 2 fun projects to solidify all the concepts we learnt. It also shows how writing reusable components is necessary since it makes maintaining code easier in the long run and also saves our time.

results.content: Good class!  The instructor goes through everything quickly and doesn't explain a lot of the reasons for doing what he's doing, so it wouldn't be as good for someone who is just getting started.  However, it was just what I needed to see how you would use hooks on a new project instead of just converting an old project from classes to hooks.  I'm still not very clear on how you know when to use some of the hooks and why.

The instructor goes through everything quickly and doesn't explain a lot of the reasons for doing what he's doing, so it wouldn't be as good for someone who is just getting started. However, it was just what I needed to see how you would use hooks on a new project instead of just converting an old project from classes to hooks. I'm still not very clear on how you know when to use some of the hooks and why.

results.content:
The course handles react basics and hooks well enough, but it is explained mostly by example. Background information and more profound knowledge is scarcely communicated. The more advanced topics are only touched upon, such as Redux, Router, Testing and component documentation. I think for the target audience, these subjects are too superficially explained. There are no assignments for the students and the course offers little challenges to try it out yourself.

What annoyed me is that a considerable amount of time is spent on repetitively styling his simple HTML elements, and we see him typing out the same css over-and-over again. That could be handled more cleverly by the instructor.
results.content_html:

results.content: Very good course for developers, and a less, but still pretty good course for beginners. I'm starting in react and was able to follow pretty much everything. However, before beginning, it's better to take some free classes elsewhere. Very well explained, but not the very first course to take.

results.content: More of an overview, not a complete course. Instructor has good explanation but lacks more complex examples/projects

results.content:
The course is ok. It does the basics ok. That said , the examples in this course are not consistently well explained, course is not well structured and it is not concise.

The examples aren't all clear - For example in the custom hook usePrevious lecture , it is not clear why a ref is used , and how that ref uses closure to keep the prior value. The real issue here is that there is no attempt to explain why a ref is used or how any of this works. There is a lot of just follow my code , vs explaining the code.

Not well structured -  UseEffect is used without any explanation prior to #29 where it is first really explained. 

Not concise - There is a lot of time in this course dedicated to him typing out examples vs other tutorials where the author pre writes the examples , and walks through them saving a lot of time.  

Overall , given the above, I am just not confident that what is in this video is helping me learn whats going on in hooks or best practice regarding hooks.
